pullRequest.body:
Add typeclass  `IsValExtension` and related lemmas.

Co-authored-by: Bichang Lei [leibichang58@ruc.edu.cn](mailto:leibichang58@ruc.edu.cn)

---

nodes.body:
### PR summary [e9e93081c7](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/14342/commits/e9e93081c7f514390bb097c572f5e2aa8d80d929)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.Valuation.ValExtension`|901|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ IsValExtension`
`+ algebraMap_injective`
`+ id`
`+ instAlgebraInteger`
`+ instIsLocalRingHomValuationInteger`
`+ instIsScalarTowerInteger`
`+ instNoZeroSMulDivisorsInteger`
`+ ofComapInteger`
`+ val_algebraMap`
`+ val_map_eq_iff`
`+ val_map_eq_one_iff`
`+ val_map_le_iff`
`+ val_map_le_one_iff`
`+ val_map_lt_iff`
`+ val_map_lt_one_iff`
`+ val_smul`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

I understand the idea beneath the `IsValExtension` declaration, but why do you want it to be a class? Which kind of interactions do you expect with type class inference? Why don't you want it to be simply an assumption that you can add?

> I understand the idea beneath the `IsValExtension` declaration, but why do you want it to be a class? Which kind of interactions do you expect with type class inference? Why don't you want it to be simply an assumption that you can add?

There are two main reasons that I want to make it a class.
1.  When working with concrete examples such as $\mathbb{C}_p/\mathbb{Q}_p$, or an arbitrary finite extension of local fields, the type class inference can infer the instance for these canonical valuations automatically. (This is the main reason.)
2. It expresses that vL is an extension of vK, so it is the setup for many definitions/theorems. For example, this can be the setup for higher ramification groups (the restriction of vL hardly equals vK due to normalization). Another example is that this can be used in the setup for Krasner's lemma, e.g. for $K^{alg}/K$ when $K$ is any rank one valued field. So making it a class saves explicit variables and enables notations like `G(vL/vK)^[u]`. (This is a relatively minor reason.)
I would love @mariainesdff and @adamtopaz opinion on this PR.

> Sorry that this PR has been sitting for so long! Overall, I think the design of `IsValExtension` is good. I do think it's worthwhile to experiment making the valuation of the base an `outParam`. Mathematically that roughly corresponds to the intuition that `vR` is "determined" by `vA`. I hope doing this would make some of the automation work better as well.

Very nice point! @jjdishere , can you give it a try?

> Sorry that this PR has been sitting for so long! Overall, I think the design of `IsValExtension` is good. I do think it's worthwhile to experiment making the valuation of the base an `outParam`. Mathematically that roughly corresponds to the intuition that `vR` is "determined" by `vA`. I hope doing this would make some of the automation work better as well.

Thank you for your advice @adamtopaz . I have discussed with @faenuccio about this possible improvement but weâ€™ve encountered an obstacle. The issue is that `vR` is only determined up to equivalent classes, even by `R`, `A` and `vA` together.

For example, when `R` is $$\mathbb{Q}_p$$, `A` is any finite extension of `R` with the discrete valuation,  we still have many choices of valuations `vR` satisfies `[IsValExtension vR vA]` e.g. The p-adic valuation sending `R` to `â„¤â‚˜â‚€`, the p-adic valuation to `NNReal`, or the valuation sending $$p$$ to `(.ofAdd -n) : â„¤â‚˜â‚€` instead of `(.ofAdd -1) : â„¤â‚˜â‚€`.

So this `vR` and thus the target of the simp lemma cannot be determined until we explicitly fill in what `vR` is. Do you have any suggestions on how to proceed?
maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by faenuccio.

> > Sorry that this PR has been sitting for so long! Overall, I think the design of `IsValExtension` is good. I do think it's worthwhile to experiment making the valuation of the base an `outParam`. Mathematically that roughly corresponds to the intuition that `vR` is "determined" by `vA`. I hope doing this would make some of the automation work better as well.
> 
> Thank you for your advice @adamtopaz . I have discussed with @faenuccio about this possible improvement but weâ€™ve encountered an obstacle. The issue is that `vR` is only determined up to equivalent classes, even by `R`, `A` and `vA` together.
> 
> For example, when `R` is Q p , `A` is any finite extension of `R` with the discrete valuation, we still have many choices of valuations `vR` satisfies `[IsValExtension vR vA]` e.g. The p-adic valuation sending `R` to `â„¤â‚˜â‚€`, the p-adic valuation to `NNReal`, or the valuation sending p to `(.ofAdd -n) : â„¤â‚˜â‚€` instead of `(.ofAdd -1) : â„¤â‚˜â‚€`.
> 
> So this `vR` and thus the target of the simp lemma cannot be determined until we explicitly fill in what `vR` is. Do you have any suggestions on how to proceed?

Yes, I understand that `vR` is only determined up to equivalence, but the point of setting it up as an outParam is that lean will just use the first `vR` that it finds in the context of typeclass inference. So one would have to carefully select which instances of `IsValExtension` are actually implemented as instances, in the sense that you should not have `IsValExtension vR vA` instances for two different `vR`'s. In the p-adic case, we could choose some standard normalization and stick with it throughout the library.  Anyway, we can think about these design decisions further after this PR is merged.

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10797437075/job/29948695596)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10797437075/job/29948696577)

Sorry that this PR has been sitting for so long! Overall, I think the design of `IsValExtension` is good. I do think it's worthwhile to experiment making the valuation of the base an `outParam`. Mathematically that roughly corresponds to the intuition that `vR` is "determined" by `vA`. I hope doing this would make some of the automation work better as well.
Given the examples you have, I agree having a class seems a good idea. Thanks!

Sorry that this PR has been sitting for so long! Overall, I think the design of `IsValExtension` is good. I do think it's worthwhile to experiment making the valuation of the base an `outParam`. Mathematically that roughly corresponds to the intuition that `vR` is "determined" by `vA`. I hope doing this would make some of the automation work better as well.

Why do you need `K` to be a field? In the application I can understand, but to define the class I would strive for a minimal set-up. My question is basically if these variables show up in the definition of the class or not.
Thank you! Actually, I found that `K` is not used in this part. I'll delete it.
Why this name of section? There is no `Coe` around... perhaps something with `AlgebraMap` would be more appropriate.
Thank you! This is a remaining section marker. When `IsValExt` is defined for `Valued`, these lemmas are coe lemma indeed. But not anymore for `IsValExt vR vA`.

```suggestion
integers of `K`, then the valuation on `A` is an extension of the valuation on `K`.
```
Thanks!
Not sure this is the best name for the section, but given its length you can skip the sectioning, perhaps. Or did you want to insert the variables inside it?
I'll reorganise the sections. The name `mk'` is really poor.
Because of issues like this, I think it would be worthwhile to experiment with making `vR` an `outParam`.

```suggestion
  /-- The valuation on `R` is equivalent to the comap of the valuation on `A` -/
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat (RingTheory/Valuation): add class IsValExtension

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat (RingTheory/Valuation) : add lemmas about valuations and notations for valued

nodes.body: I understand the idea beneath the `IsValExtension` declaration, but why do you want it to be a class? Which kind of interactions do you expect with type class inference? Why don't you want it to be simply an assumption that you can add?

> I understand the idea beneath the `IsValExtension` declaration, but why do you want it to be a class? Which kind of interactions do you expect with type class inference? Why don't you want it to be simply an assumption that you can add?

There are two main reasons that I want to make it a class.
1.  When working with concrete examples such as $\mathbb{C}_p/\mathbb{Q}_p$, or an arbitrary finite extension of local fields, the type class inference can infer the instance for these canonical valuations automatically. (This is the main reason.)
2. It expresses that vL is an extension of vK, so it is the setup for many definitions/theorems. For example, this can be the setup for higher ramification groups (the restriction of vL hardly equals vK due to normalization). Another example is that this can be used in the setup for Krasner's lemma, e.g. for $K^{alg}/K$ when $K$ is any rank one valued field. So making it a class saves explicit variables and enables notations like `G(vL/vK)^[u]`. (This is a relatively minor reason.)
Given the examples you have, I agree having a class seems a good idea. Thanks!
I would love @mariainesdff and @adamtopaz opinion on this PR.

Sorry that this PR has been sitting for so long! Overall, I think the design of `IsValExtension` is good. I do think it's worthwhile to experiment making the valuation of the base an `outParam`. Mathematically that roughly corresponds to the intuition that `vR` is "determined" by `vA`. I hope doing this would make some of the automation work better as well.

> Sorry that this PR has been sitting for so long! Overall, I think the design of `IsValExtension` is good. I do think it's worthwhile to experiment making the valuation of the base an `outParam`. Mathematically that roughly corresponds to the intuition that `vR` is "determined" by `vA`. I hope doing this would make some of the automation work better as well.

Very nice point! @jjdishere , can you give it a try?

> Sorry that this PR has been sitting for so long! Overall, I think the design of `IsValExtension` is good. I do think it's worthwhile to experiment making the valuation of the base an `outParam`. Mathematically that roughly corresponds to the intuition that `vR` is "determined" by `vA`. I hope doing this would make some of the automation work better as well.

Thank you for your advice @adamtopaz . I have discussed with @faenuccio about this possible improvement but weâ€™ve encountered an obstacle. The issue is that `vR` is only determined up to equivalent classes, even by `R`, `A` and `vA` together.

For example, when `R` is $$\mathbb{Q}_p$$, `A` is any finite extension of `R` with the discrete valuation,  we still have many choices of valuations `vR` satisfies `[IsValExtension vR vA]` e.g. The p-adic valuation sending `R` to `â„¤â‚˜â‚€`, the p-adic valuation to `NNReal`, or the valuation sending $$p$$ to `(.ofAdd -n) : â„¤â‚˜â‚€` instead of `(.ofAdd -1) : â„¤â‚˜â‚€`.

So this `vR` and thus the target of the simp lemma cannot be determined until we explicitly fill in what `vR` is. Do you have any suggestions on how to proceed?

Mathematically that roughly corresponds to the intuition that `vR` is "determined" by `vA`. I hope doing this would make some of the automation work better as well.

Yes, I understand that `vR` is only determined up to equivalence, but the point of setting it up as an outParam is that lean will just use the first `vR` that it finds in the context of typeclass inference. So one would have to carefully select which instances of `IsValExtension` are actually implemented as instances, in the sense that you should not have `IsValExtension vR vA` instances for two different `vR`'s. In the p-adic case, we could choose some standard normalization and stick with it throughout the library.  Anyway, we can think about these design decisions further after this PR is merged.
